finding: rs76662990 was found to be significantly associated with age-related cognitive changes, as verified by GWAS with a p-value of 8.00E-6, highlighting its relevance to cognitive traits.
title: Systems genetics identifies the association between Enc1 and cognitive function in the hippocampus

finding: Both rs298387 and its connection to other measurements were reported, specifically with the PHF-tau and neurofibrillary tangles measurement phenotypes, suggesting its importance in cognitive decline. It was noted along with rs7949874 with a p-value of 3E-8 and with rs9076 in the context of neurofibrillary tangles at a p-value of 1.00E-12.
title: Systems genetics identifies the association between Enc1 and cognitive function in the hippocampus

finding: The SNP rs10060174 was identified as having a significant association with the sensitivity of pancreatic cancer cells to different PI3K inhibitors. The study reported that how tumors expressed various PI3K isoforms could guide personalized treatment approaches and provided insights into the adaptive signaling responses to isoform-selective PI3K inhibition.
title: Phosphoproteomics identifies PI3K inhibitor-selective adaptive responses in pancreatic cancer cell therapy and resistance

finding: The minor allele of rs7704909, along with two other GWAS-identified risk variants (rs12518194 and rs4307059), was significantly associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). These SNPs acted synergistically to promote the expression of the lncRNA MSNP1AS, which was highly enriched in the postmortem cerebral cortex of ASD patients, leading to the inhibition of moesin production and dysregulation of neuronal architecture.
title: Genetic regulation of lncRNA expression in the whole human brain

finding: The minor allele of rs12518194, in combination with rs7704909 and rs4307059, was significantly linked to autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This set of variants promoted lncRNA MSNP1AS expression, which was found to be enriched in the cerebral cortex of ASD patients and contributed to the dysregulation of neuronal architecture through modulation of moesin production.
title: Genetic regulation of lncRNA expression in the whole human brain

finding: The minor allele of rs4307059, along with two other identified variants (rs7704909 and rs12518194), was associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). These SNPs fostered the expression of lncRNA MSNP1AS, which was significantly expressed in the cerebral cortex of ASD patients, affecting moesin production and leading to neuronal architecture dysregulation.
title: Genetic regulation of lncRNA expression in the whole human brain

finding: The derived allele of rs373863828 in the CREBRF gene was significantly associated with several adiposity traits among Native Hawaiians, showing a large effect size on body mass index (BMI) of approximately 1.28 kg/m^2 per allele, and an effect size estimate of 0.214 standard deviations (P = 7.5×10^-5). This association also extended to waist and hip circumferences and provided a protective effect against type 2 diabetes (T2D), with odds ratios reflecting increased obesity risk (OR=1.096, P = 9.52E-5) and diminished T2D risk (OR=0.935, P = 0.0162). The study highlighted the absence of imputed representation for Polynesian-specific variants due to reliance on European-centric databases.
title: Population specific reference panels are crucial for the genetic analyses of Native Hawai’ians: an example of the CREBRF locus

finding: The SNP rs26279 in the MSH3 gene was found to be associated with an increased risk of cancer as reported in a meta-analysis. This finding highlighted the role of MSH3 in DNA mismatch repair processes and its potential implications in oncogenesis, thereby providing evidence linking this specific polymorphism to cancer susceptibility.
title: Msh2-Msh3 DNA-binding is not sufficient to promote trinucleotide repeat expansions in Saccharomyces cerevisiae

finding: The study identified rs17622517 as a risk variant for autoimmune disease located in an intron of C5ORF56, which had a significant cis-eQTL effect on the transcription factor IRF1 during early immune stimulus. This SNP was shown to function as an enhancer for IRF1 and was considered a causal variant influencing the inter-individual response to immune stimuli, particularly affecting downstream immune pathways. Its association with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) reinforced its relevance to autoimmune traits.
title: An autoimmune disease risk variant has a trans master regulatory effect mediated by IRF1 under immune stimulation

finding: The rs2853669 polymorphism located at -245 bp from the ATG start site of the TERT gene disrupted a preexisting non-canonical ETS2 binding site adjacent to an E-box in the proximal region of the TERT promoter. This disruption modulated the effect of mutations within the TERT promoter on disease outcomes across various cancers, highlighting its significance in cancer biology.
title: Occurrence, functionality, and abundance of the TERT promoter mutations

finding: The SNP rs35395 in the SLC45A2 gene was related to lighter skin pigmentation, showing evidence of strong selection during the period of 2500-5000 years ago. The study highlighted how depigmentation was potentially advantageous for vitamin D synthesis in European populations due to environmental and dietary shifts.
title: Fast and accurate estimation of selection coefficients and allele histories from ancient and modern DNA

finding: The variant rs736801 was associated with breast cancer risk at sub genome-wide significance levels (P = 8 x 10^-8). Molecular analyses indicated that the risk allele led to a reduction in IRF1 expression. This reduction was significant in regulating immune interactions, as IRF1 plays a critical role in the IFNγ signaling pathway and antigen presentation machinery.
title: Pooled genetic screens identify breast cancer risk genes involved in evasion from T cell-mediated killing

finding: The SNP rs11950533 was identified as the index variant in a PD GWAS locus. In the context of scRNA-seq data, it was associated with the expression of the gene CAMLG in dopaminergic neuron cell clusters. An eQTL for CAMLG was specifically detected, demonstrating a high correlation with the PD GWAS signal. This association suggested a regulatory role for CAMLG in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease that became detectable during the differentiation process of iPSCs to DA neurons.
title: The Foundational data initiative for Parkinson’s disease (FOUNDIN-PD): enabling efficient translation from genetic maps to mechanism

finding: The RNA editing QTL (rs2282810) in CDX1 was associated with the expression of SLC6A7. It was shown that this relationship affected the editing event in SLC6A7, indicating potential implications in neurotransmitter recovery and neurodegenerative biomarkers.
title: Genetic control of RNA editing in Neurodegenerative disease

finding: This expression QTL was associated with the regulatory functions of CDX1 on SLC6A7 to confer effects on related RNA editing events, linking it to neurodegenerative pathways.
title: Genetic control of RNA editing in Neurodegenerative disease

finding: The SNP rs187653 was found to disrupt ARNT2 binding motifs, signaling its involvement in the regulation of ASC genes that are implicated in schizophrenia within the context of neuropsychiatric disorder mechanisms.
title: Age-specific gene signatures underlying the transcriptomes and functional connectomes of human cerebral cortex

finding: This SNP was previously identified in association with global FA, forceps minor FA, and projection fibres FA in the context of white matter tracts. It was the only SNP across three eQTL scores that reached genome-wide significance.
title: Expression quantitative trait loci-derived scores and white matter microstructure in UK Biobank: a novel approach to integrating genetics and neuroimaging

finding: The variant rs116171826 was associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) through joint under-expression outliers in RNA and protein signals. This finding supported the potential role of prioritized variants in AD pathobiology.
title: The functional impact of rare variation across the regulatory cascade

finding: The rs149274963 variant was implicated in Alzheimer's disease (AD) due to its association with joint under-expression outliers in both RNA and protein signals, highlighting its relevance in AD pathobiology.
title: The functional impact of rare variation across the regulatory cascade

finding: The rs10071918 variant was part of the findings for Alzheimer's disease (AD), identified through RNA and protein signal under-expression outliers, underscoring its potential role in AD-related mechanisms.
title: The functional impact of rare variation across the regulatory cascade

finding: The SNP rs10040091 was associated with chromosomal instability in Hodgkin lymphoma, and its significance was reaffirmed in the study by Cuceu et al. (2018), which highlighted mechanisms behind chromosome breaks influenced by the presence of viral elements, particularly the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). This linkage established a broader understanding of how similar mechanisms might apply to other cancers, including breast cancer.
title: Chromosome breaks in breast cancers occur near herpes tumor virus sequences

finding: The SNP rs2563297, located on chromosome 5, was a CC-GWAS-specific locus defining differences between schizophrenia (SCZ) and major depressive disorder (MDD). It showed significant SMR colocalization with multiple gene-tissue pairs, implicating five protocadherin alpha genes, which are important for neuronal connections, and the NDUFA2 gene associated with Leigh syndrome. Additionally, SNPs in this locus had associations with schizophrenia, depressive symptoms, neuroticism, educational attainment, intelligence, and blood pressure, indicating its pleiotropic nature.
title: Identifying loci with different allele frequencies among cases of eight psychiatric disorders using CC-GWAS

finding: The analysis revealed that rs875741 was associated with mean corpuscular volume (MCV), highlighting its significant role within the genetic variants affecting blood phenotypes. Additionally, the correlation between rs875741 and nearby alleles was evidenced by a squared correlation (r²) metric, illustrating its relevance in the regulatory network during erythroid differentiation.
title: Transcription factor networks disproportionately enrich for heritability of blood cell phenotypes

finding: Similar to rs875741, rs875742 was implicated in the differential gene expression within hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs). Specifically, gene editing efficiencies and relative CPEB4 expression levels were examined in HSPCs edited with sgRNAs targeting rs875742, demonstrating its influence in the expression of CPEB4, a gene critical to erythroid lineage differentiation.
title: Transcription factor networks disproportionately enrich for heritability of blood cell phenotypes

finding: Associated with various functional connectivity traits, rs34522 in the 5q14.3 region was found to influence intrinsic brain activity, highlighting its relevance to cognitive processes.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: The study identified the SNP rs10065372, located at position +313 inside exon 2 of the IRGM gene on chromosome 5q33.1. This SNP was previously associated with severe sepsis, which has a high fatality rate. Although the specific implications of this SNP in the context of atherosclerosis and plaque rupture were not fully explored, the finding underscored the potential relevance of IRGM in inflammatory diseases, including its role in macrophage apoptosis and the mechanisms of acute coronary syndrome.
title: IRGM/Irgm1 Aggravates Progression of Atherosclerosis by Inducing Macrophage Apoptosis

finding: The SNP rs351855 in FGFR4 was associated with suppressing cytotoxic CD8+ T cell infiltration and promoting higher levels of immunosuppressive regulatory T cells through increased STAT3 signaling in murine models of breast and lung cancer.
title: Germline variants that influence the tumor immune microenvironment also drive response to immunotherapy

finding: The SNP rs10050691 was associated with the implementation of the LandTrendr algorithm on Google Earth Engine. This algorithm utilized remote sensing data to assess forest disturbances over time, demonstrating its relevance in monitoring changes in primary forest areas.
title: European Primary Forest Database (EPFD) v2.0

finding: The SNP rs26279 located in MSH3 was found to be associated with an increased cancer risk, as detailed in a meta-analysis conducted by Miao et al. in 2015. This finding indicated that variations in the MSH3 gene, particularly this polymorphism, could influence genomic stability, potentially linking it to malignancies, which is critical given the context of Msh2-Msh3's role in both DNA repair and genomic instability.
title: Msh2-Msh3 interferes with DNA metabolism in vivo

finding: In studies from London cohorts, rs12654448 was significantly associated with cigarette consumption (p=0.00125) and likelihood of cessation, especially in heavy smokers (p=0.0003397). The minor allele was linked to a lower degree of dependence and decreased cigarette consumption, also associated with age at onset of weekly smoking in the Finnish twins cohort (p=0.00105).
title: Identification of Slit3 as a locus affecting nicotine preference in zebrafish and human smoking behaviour

finding: This SNP was found to be significantly associated with level of cigarette consumption (p=0.00227) and was re-confirmed for heavy smokers (p=0.0008575). Furthermore, it correlated with DSM-IV nicotine dependence symptoms (p=0.0322) and age at onset of weekly smoking (p=0.00116). Again, the minor allele indicated lower dependence and decreased cigarette consumption.
title: Identification of Slit3 as a locus affecting nicotine preference in zebrafish and human smoking behaviour

finding: In addition to rs12654448 and rs17734503, rs11742567 was associated with cigarette consumption (p=0.004715) and quitting behavior, with significant effects observed in light smokers (p=0.003909), suggesting a relevant role of this SNP in smoking behavior.
title: Identification of Slit3 as a locus affecting nicotine preference in zebrafish and human smoking behaviour

finding: The SNP rs73801920 was linked to D5S818 and was noted for having a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.1214. Its observation in the context of a population study indicated its utility in forensic genetics by providing additional genetic markers for individualization.
title: The concordance of length- and sequence-based STRs used in forensic markers with guidance for practice

finding: For rs11950944, the analysis revealed that the SNP led to an enhanced binding of p300 and other cofactors in a way that deviated significantly from the reference allele. This SNP served as a notable example of how ncSNPs could lead to enhanced association with regulatory factors.
title: Customizable high-throughput platform for profiling cofactor recruitment to DNA to characterize cis-regulatory elements and screen non-coding single-nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: The SNP rs13184712 was linked to the regulation of macrophage infiltration in tumors, indicating its role in the immune landscape of malignancies and the impact on therapeutic outcomes, particularly in the study of macrophages in cancer.
title: Temporal genomic analysis of melanoma rejection identifies regulators of tumor immune evasion

finding: The intergenic SNP rs4532315 was highlighted in the meta-analysis as having a significant association with T2D, p-value recorded at 9.80 x 10^-9.
title: A Novel Type 2 Diabetes Locus in sub-Saharan Africans, ZRANB3, is Implicated in Beta Cell Proliferation

finding: Similar to other notable loci, rs256228 showed that its most proximal gene was significantly expressed and specific to dopamine neurons, indicating its relevance in PD.
title: Single cell spatial transcriptomic and translatomic profiling of dopaminergic neurons in health, ageing and disease

finding: The genetic variant rs17171731 was identified as a candidate SNP in the atrial fibrillation (AF) GWAS locus on chromosome 5q31. This SNP was shown to control the expression of FAM13B in the left atrium, with the AF risk allele exhibiting less enhancer activity compared to the protective allele. The functional analysis indicated that the risk allele could bind an additional protein acting as a transcriptional repressor, which may contribute to increased susceptibility to AF by altering the expression of over 1000 cardiomyocyte genes.
title: Causal SNP regulating FAM13B expression identified for the Chr. 5q31 atrial fibrillation susceptibility locus

finding: The SNP rs10040095 was reported in the context of differentiation therapy targeting the beta-Catenin/CBP interaction in pancreatic cancer. The study indicated that this SNP was linked to the functional interactions of CBP, which is crucial in processes like transcriptional regulation and tumorigenesis. The involvement of this SNP in reference to cancer highlights its relevance in the molecular mechanisms underlying cancer biology.
title: Planarian CREB-binding protein (CBP) gene family regulates stem cell maintenance and differentiation

finding: The SNP rs13153658 was linked to SIK2's role in ovarian cancer cells as highlighted in the study. It was used to explore the effects of the small-molecule inhibitor MRIA9, which provided novel insights into SIK2 functions in the cell cycle, suggesting its relevance in cancer biology.
title: Shifting the selectivity of pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidin-7(8H)-one inhibitors towards the salt-inducible kinase (SIK) subfamily

finding: The variant rs2431697 was identified as likely causal for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It was located in a functional regulatory element influencing miR-146a expression, with genetic and epigenomic analyses demonstrating that this variant acts as a distal enhancer modulating miR-146a expression in a cell-type dependent manner. The T allele was associated with an increased risk of SLE, influencing the binding of NF-kB and chromatin accessibility, thus affecting miR-146a expression.
title: SLE non-coding Genetic Risk Variant Determines the Epigenetic Dysfunction of an Immune Cell Specific Enhancer that Controls Disease-critical microRNA Expression

finding: The variant rs57095329, located in the promoter of miR-146a, was shown to significantly influence miR-146a expression by modulating Ets1 binding, relevant to its involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus pathology.
title: SLE non-coding Genetic Risk Variant Determines the Epigenetic Dysfunction of an Immune Cell Specific Enhancer that Controls Disease-critical microRNA Expression

finding: The variant rs2431098 was included as part of the 95% credible set in the replication cohort along with rs2431697, suggesting its potential role in SLE pathogenesis but with less direct evidence than rs2431697.
title: SLE non-coding Genetic Risk Variant Determines the Epigenetic Dysfunction of an Immune Cell Specific Enhancer that Controls Disease-critical microRNA Expression

finding: The rs2569190 SNP in the CD14 gene was associated with coronary artery disease in T2DM patients, indicating its relevance in inflammation and atherosclerosis.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of potential key genes and mechanisms in type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The single-nucleotide polymorphism rs2287926 in the versican gene (VCAN) was associated with phenotypes related to lean mass, lean appendicular mass, and metabolic protection. This suggested that versican might play a significant role as a genetic modifier of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) pathology.
title: In dystrophic mdx hindlimb muscles where fibrosis is limited versican haploinsufficiency transiently improves contractile function without decreasing inflammation

finding: The analysis revealed that rs185220 is a tiQTL, which disrupted both initiation sites in a divergent pair on the plus and minus strands, resulting in a substantial decrease in the quantity of transcription initiation. This finding was largely attributed to the loss of a strong SP/KLF binding site on the minor allele, as confirmed by the predictions from the CLIPNET model.
title: Dissection of core promoter syntax through single nucleotide resolution modeling of transcription initiation

finding: The EPHA1 protective allele (rs1080826) was linked to lower levels of Aβ42_TX, Aβ42_FA, and total tau_FA, highlighting potential protective effects against AD.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The SNP rs56167332 corresponded to the alt-k-mer 'GGAAGT', which matched the motif of the transcription factor SPI1. This SNP was part of the top 100 SNPs analyzed, with SPI1 showing the highest ΔMOCCS2score contribution, accounting for 17% of the combined ΔMOCCS2scores of these SNPs, reinforcing the hypothesis of its predictive capability related to TF binding.
title: MOCCS profile analysis clarifies the cell type dependency of transcription factor-binding sequences and cis-regulatory SNPs in humans

finding: The SNP rs13163946 was associated with drug repurposing strategies in pancreatic cancer treatment as reported by De Lellis et al. in their 2021 publication. The findings indicated that this SNP could influence treatment efficacy, particularly in relation to the use of gemcitabine (GEM) and targeted kinase inhibitors in pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) therapies.
title: Gemcitabine and ATR inhibitors synergize to kill PDAC cells by blocking DNA damage response

finding: SNP rs1038143 showed association with high-density lipoprotein (HDL), corroborating findings related to the MGAT1 locus, which showed distinct effects on lipid levels in Samoans compared to other groups.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: The SNP rs10060207 was associated with hypersialylation in cancer, which is implicated in the modulation of inflammation and presents therapeutic opportunities. This finding suggested that the effect of carbohydrate sulfation, highlighted in the context of Siglec ligands and cancer, could be relevant to this specific SNP.
title: Carbohydrate sulfation as a mechanism for fine-tuning Siglec ligands

finding: The study identified rs6893807 as a trans expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) associated with IQ, which affected the expression of the SCZ risk gene BNIP3L. This gene was critical due to its role in mitophagy, the process of removing damaged mitochondria, and was prioritized in the largest genome-wide association study of schizophrenia. The significant association observed (P = 1.60E-05, adjusted P = 0.025) indicated the potential impact of MEF2C disruptions on mitochondrial dysfunction and cognitive phenotypes.
title: Direct targets of MEF2C are enriched for genes associated with schizophrenia and cognitive function and are involved in neurogenesis and mitochondrial function

finding: The SNP rs13174411 was identified as a biomarker associated with immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) response in bladder cancer (BC). In the context of the study, this SNP was highlighted for its potential role in predicting treatment efficacy, specifically its correlation with TIDE status in subtypes of BC. The finding indicated that the presence of rs13174411 may help in distinguishing between the subtypes, thereby improving the understanding of patient eligibility for immunotherapy.
title: Three Conserved Immune Dysfunction and Exclusion Subtypes in Bladder and Pan-cancers: Prognostic and Immunotherapeutic Significance

finding: The rs6190 SNP (p.R23K) was found to be associated with enhanced muscle strength, lean body mass, and improved metabolic health in young adult men. In studies conducted in transgenic mice, the homozygous mutant (GR^R24K/R24K) compared to non-mutant littermates (GR^wt/wt) demonstrated increased muscle insulin sensitivity, better glucose homeostasis, and greater exercise endurance, suggesting a pro-metabolic function attributable to the SNP. Transcriptomic and epigenomic analyses also identified Foxc1 and Arid5A as novel targets of mutant glucocorticoid receptor transactivation, contributing to the metabolic benefits observed.
title: The human genetic variant rs6190 unveils Foxc1 and Arid5a as novel pro-metabolic targets of the glucocorticoid receptor in muscle

finding: SNP rs3088073 was noted in relation to heterozygosity in the ATRX gene among the F7cl15, ASD, F002, F7cl4, CE, and CD human iPSCs. The presence of heterozygosity at this SNP contributed to a detailed analysis of allelic expression in the ATRX gene, further elucidating the expression dynamics of X-linked genes with respect to XCI erosion.
title: Erosion of X-Chromosome Inactivation in female hiPSCs is heterogeneous and persists during differentiation

finding: The variant rs182677317 was annotated as having conflicting interpretations of pathogenicity for a rare disease known as ciliary dyskinesia. The NyuWa dataset indicated that this variant had an allele frequency greater than 1%, suggesting it may not be pathogenic as previously thought, thus providing new insights into its potential role.
title: NyuWa Genome Resource: Deep Whole Genome Sequencing Based Chinese Population Variation Profile and Reference Panel

finding: The SNP rs13184520 was identified in the context of acral melanoma (AM) research. It was linked to the response to PARP inhibitors, indicating its role in the therapeutic strategies for melanoma, particularly AM, which is known to be biologically distinct from non-acral cutaneous melanoma. The findings suggested that patients with certain genotypes could potentially benefit from targeted treatments leveraging this SNP.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase inhibition leads to regression of acral melanoma by targeting the tumor microenvironment

finding: The rare mis-sense SNP rs78408340 within the gene PAM had a high significance (p=6.10×10^-10) and indicated a functional role in regulating lean mass, supported by evidence of its association with PAM expression.
title: Genome-wide association study of appendicular lean mass in UK Biobank cohort

finding: The intergenic variant rs400596, located between PAM and SLC06A1, was associated with PAM expression levels in whole blood (p=2.51×10^-21) and protein levels in peripheral blood (p=2.51×10^-30), underlining its regulatory importance.
title: Genome-wide association study of appendicular lean mass in UK Biobank cohort

finding: The SNP rs76792388 was one of the two independent instrumental variables identified for RASGEF1C in microglia, demonstrating a strong association with AD risk. Its study-wide cis-eQTL false discovery rate (FDR) was reported as 2.40×10⁻⁴, reflecting its significant impact on gene expression related to AD.
title: Single-cell Mendelian randomisation identifies cell-type specific genetic effects on human brain disease and behaviour

finding: The SNP rs10077711, alongside rs76792388, served as an independent instrumental variable for RASGEF1C in microglia, contributing to the regulatory control of RASGEF1C expression affecting AD risk. The study-wide cis-eQTL FDR for this SNP was reported as 4.62×10⁻², reinforcing its relevance.
title: Single-cell Mendelian randomisation identifies cell-type specific genetic effects on human brain disease and behaviour

finding: The SNP rs6870603 had a P-value of 1.04 x 10^-8 for SmokingInitiation and was predicted to affect open chromatin activity specifically in cortical excitatory neurons, suggesting its role in the genetic underpinnings of addiction.
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: Similar to rs6870603, the SNP rs7712167 was also associated with SmokingInitiation (P-value of 8.79 x 10^-9) and predicted to affect only EXC open chromatin activity, further reinforcing its significance in addiction-related genetic architecture.
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: The SNP rs12653946 exhibited an odds ratio (OR) of 0.53 and a BH FDR of 0.032, replicating its association with ERG status.
title: Germline determinants of the prostate tumor genome

finding: SNP rs7735176 was found to be associated with the reproductive subtype with a meta-analysis P-value of 1.17×10^-8. It was one of two adjacent SNPs in perfect LD located upstream of the CDH10 gene.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: SNP rs16893866 was equally associated with the reproductive subtype along with rs7735176, with a similar P-value of 1.17×10^-8. It was imputed in Stage 1 and showed an odds ratio of 5.09.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The study identified a particularly strong association for SNP rs2736100, which is associated with the TERT gene. This gene is recognized as a known cancer gene whose expression is linked to an increased risk of cancer and is hypothesized to impair telomere maintenance. The analysis was conducted using the SafeGENIE algorithm and validated against results from the centralized algorithm REGENIE, demonstrating high agreement between the two methods.
title: Secure and federated linear mixed model association tests

finding: The SNP rs13174389 was associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) as reported in the study. It was identified in the context of examining the E2F1 and E2F8 transcription factors, which were shown to regulate essential processes like cell proliferation and survival in pancreatic cancer cells. The expression levels of E2F factors correlated with the activation of apoptosis and mitosis pathways in PDAC, indicating a potentially significant role of this SNP in tumorigenesis.
title: E2F transcription factors promote tumorigenicity in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma

finding: The SNP rs4841 was associated with genotype-dependent alignment variability of the pseudogene transcript RP11-343H5.4 across different frequencies in human populations. This relationship demonstrated that the expression of this pseudogene was impacted by genetic variability, marking it as an important genetic feature in transcript clustering and expression analysis.
title: Patterns of unwanted biological and technical expression variation across 49 human tissues

finding: The SNP rs13153841 was highlighted in the study by Saraiva et al. (2021) as a significant marker for the expression of HLA-DR in cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), establishing a validated predictive biomarker for breast cancer response to treatments.
title: Enhancing HLA-DR in Cytotoxic T Lymphocytes is crucial for the development of efficient adoptive T cell Therapies for Breast Cancer

finding: The SNP rs113313884 was identified as a significant finding in the GWAS of chronic pain and was located in the intronic region of the gene ADAMTS6 on chromosome 6. Although it showed suggestive association only with multisite chronic pain, it was implied to contribute to the understanding of CP in relation to its anatomical and physiological roles, particularly in connection with osteoarthritis and heel bone mineral density.
title: Genetic, lifestyle and environmental risk factors for chronic pain revealed through GWAS

finding: The SNP rs11950533 was associated with the DDX46 gene, which was found to be relevant for Parkinson's disease (PD) within a GWAS interval. It was reported that the pre-mRNA splicing pattern of DDX46 was altered in midbrain dopamine (mDA) cells originating from the PRKN (Ex 3del) mutant, suggesting that this mutation contributes to specific splicing changes linked with PD. Notably, the study also indicated variations in DDX46 protein levels throughout differentiation in these mutant cells, which could influence the alternative splicing regulated by U2 snRNP, thereby potentially affecting PD symptoms.
title: Comparison of Alternative pre-mRNA Splicing and Gene Expression Patterns in Midbrain Lineage Cells Carrying Familial Parkinson’s Disease Mutations

finding: The variant rs78853309 (c.7502G>C;p.(R2501P)) in the DNAH5 gene was identified in an individual with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) and situs inversus (SI). This variant was previously reported as damaging and was found to be highly conserved and predicted to have significant biological impact.
title: Rare variants in dynein heavy chain genes in two individuals with situs inversus and developmental dyslexia

finding: The variant rs754466516 (c.12043T>G;p.(Y4015D)) in the DNAH5 gene was novel and identified in the same individual as rs78853309. It was classified as damaging, predicted to impact the function of the protein and also linked to PCD.
title: Rare variants in dynein heavy chain genes in two individuals with situs inversus and developmental dyslexia

finding: SNP rs11168036 was linked to PFDN1, a gene encoding a subunit of the prefoldin complex, which exhibited lower expression in venule smooth muscle cells in AD. This association indicated dysregulation of protein folding machinery within cerebrovascular cells, suggesting a mechanism related to AD pathogenesis.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs13153781 was associated with the modulation of VEGF levels in plasma, which was highlighted as a prognostic bio-marker in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). This finding suggested that the SNP may play a role in the tumor's microenvironment and disease progression, marking it as a critical factor in understanding HNSCC pathology.
title: RNA-sequencing manifests the intrinsic role of MAPKAPK2 in facilitating molecular crosstalk during HNSCC pathogenesis

finding: The SNP rs2853669 was identified as the top prioritized variant by the regBase_REG_Common model, achieving the highest PHRED score in the 5p15.33 TERT region. It was previously validated through extensive functional experiments to disrupt TERT promoter activity and confer cancer risk, demonstrating its significance as a causal variant.
title: Whole genome base-wise aggregation and functional prediction for human non-coding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs7732179 showed greater significance in the conditional analysis for major depression (MD) and also exhibited evidence of association with SCZ with opposite directions of effect, where the A allele increases risk for MD but is protective for SCZ and bipolar disorder (BIP). It is associated with the expression of PCDHA7.
title: Conditional GWAS analysis identifies putative disorder-specific SNPs for psychiatric disorders

finding: The TERT long allele (rs2736100) was associated with increased risk of cerebrovascular disease mortality, with a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.20 (95% CI [1.03, 1.40], p=0.02). Additionally, it was found to be associated with decreased risk of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), presenting a HR of 0.75 (95% CI [0.57, 0.99], p=0.04). This finding suggested a complex relationship between telomere length variations and specific aging-related mortality risks.
title: Genetically Increased Telomere Length and Aging-related Physical and Cognitive Traits in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs1444732 in the GPX4 gene was found to be significantly associated with increased mean pulmonary arterial pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance in carriers compared to noncarriers. Specifically, the median pulmonary arterial pressure for carriers was 34.5 mmHg, while for noncarriers it was 31.0 mmHg. Similarly, pulmonary vascular resistance was higher in carriers (4.8) compared to noncarriers (2.7). These findings underscore a genetic link between the anti-ferroptosis mechanism of GPX4 and the severity of pulmonary hypertension in humans.
title: Ferroptosis Promotes Pulmonary Hypertension

finding: The SNP rs12916, which was associated with statin use, revealed a univariable MR estimate showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.33 for its effect on ischemic stroke (IS) in the MEGASTROKE and UK Biobank studies, indicating a harmful direction. However, in multivariable MR adjusted for major survival causes and ischemic stroke, the OR for rs12916 on stroke was corrected to 0.81 in the UK Biobank, suggesting a protective effect against stroke.
title: Use of multivariable Mendelian randomization to address biases due to competing risk before recruitment

finding: Variants such as rs10069690 were associated with TN disease, marking them as critical in the context of HR-negative breast cancers.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This variant exhibited a substantial association with luminal A-like subtypes.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This SNP was identified for its connections to PR-status and ER heterogeneity.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Reported connections with risk in ER-positive subtypes under genetic analyses.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The SNP rs351855, leading to a Gly388Arg alteration in the FGFR4 gene, was detected in EGY1, EGY6, and EGY8. It was associated with waist-to-hip ratio adjusted for body mass index, correlating with the participants' obesity-related clinical conditions.
title: Complete genome sequence and analysis of nine Egyptian females with clinical information from different geographic regions in Egypt

finding: The KIBRA rs17070145 SNP was identified as a potential regulator of human memory performance. Carriers of the T allele displayed significantly improved episodic memory performance and greater physiological engagement of the hippocampus during tasks. The study confirmed that T-allele carriers had higher KIBRA mRNA expression in the hippocampus and better cognitive performance compared to CC genotype carriers.
title: KIBRA-PKCγ signaling pathway modulates memory performance in mice and humans

finding: The variant rs114694170 resided in a promoter-proximal cis-regulatory element (CRE) of the MEF2C gene. It was previously nominated as a causal variant affecting platelet count, but the experimental evidence regarding the CRE was lacking until validated by HCR-FlowFISH. Evidence from HCR-FlowFISH established rs114694170 as a functional regulator of MEF2C.
title: HCR-FlowFISH: A flexible CRISPR screening method to identify cis-regulatory elements and their target genes

finding: The rs1432621 variant was linked to increased collagen density in the tissue from sun-exposed skin. Although no specific gene expression was significantly associated after correction, pathway enrichment highlighted pathways related to UV response and epithelial transition.
title: HistoGWAS: An AI-enabled Framework for Automated Genetic Analysis of Tissue Phenotypes in Histology Cohorts

finding: The SNP rs458609 was found to be highly correlated with both VNTRs TR09 and TR17, exhibiting a correlation value of r² > 0.96. This finding was significant in the context of genetic studies focusing on the SLC6A3 gene.
title: A Novel Hyper-Variable Variable Number Tandem Repeat in the Dopamine Transporter Gene (SLC6A3)

finding: Similar to rs458609, the SNP rs393795 also showed a high correlation with VNTRs TR09 and TR17, with an r² value exceeding 0.96. This correlation provided further support for the genetic studies associated with the SLC6A3 gene.
title: A Novel Hyper-Variable Variable Number Tandem Repeat in the Dopamine Transporter Gene (SLC6A3)

finding: This SNP was prioritized in credible sets associated with BMI, exhibiting high posterior probabilities.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: The rs7719499-G allele was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with the reproduction-enhancing allele of the antagonistically pleiotropic variant rs13164856, and it was associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
title: Evidence for the role of selection for reproductively advantageous alleles in human aging

finding: The variant rs13164856, associated with the reproduction-enhancing allele, was linked to increased susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases, highlighting the antagonistically pleiotropic effects of reproduction-enhancing alleles.
title: Evidence for the role of selection for reproductively advantageous alleles in human aging

finding: The SNP rs13163928 was associated with predicting the curability of locally advanced head and neck cancer patients treated with chemoradiation therapy. Specifically, a CENP-A subnuclear localization pattern was identified as a potential biomarker for patient outcomes, indicating that the spatial organization of CENP-A may influence tumor response to therapy.
title: Direct recruitment of Mis18 to interphase spindle poles promotes CENP-A chromatin assembly

finding: The analysis revealed that individuals homozygous for the rs1056893 variant had very low expression levels of ERAP2 in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDM). This SNP's association with a decrease in ERAP2 expression correlated with the increased susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease without a significant association with disease status.
title: The association between transcriptional regulation of macrophage differentiation and activation and genetic susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease

finding: The SNP rs10040118 was associated with the phenomenon of polyploid giant cancer cells (PGCCs) in epithelial ovarian tumors, which were linked to resilience against antimitotic drugs, particularly under conditions of hypoxia and following paclitaxel treatment. This SNP was considered a positive and original finding as it contributed to the understanding of the involvement of the unfolded protein response (UPR) pathway in PGCC formation and tumor aggression.
title: Linking endoplasmic reticulum stress to polyploidy in ovarian cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs2020209 was linked to the expression of thioredoxin in various states of tumor oxygenation, which was detailed in the publication by Karlenius and Tonissen. This study highlighted the role of thioredoxin in tumor microenvironments, suggesting its involvement in oxidative stress responses and potentially influencing re-epithelialization processes related to wound healing.
title: Impairment of the Hif-1α regulatory pathway in Foxn1-deficient (Foxn1−/−) mice affects the skin wound healing process

finding: The SNP rs13163990 was identified as a positive and original finding related to the neural mechanisms involved in cancer cachexia. The study demonstrated that peripheral IL-6 influences AP neurons, provoking hyperactivity in these neurons, which was linked to cachexia in tumor-bearing mice. The findings suggested that targeting this pathway may provide therapeutic options for cancer-associated cachexia.
title: Area postrema neurons mediate interleukin-6 function in cancer-associated cachexia

finding: This SNP, located near FGF10, was found to have a most significant association in a parietal segment, specifically segment 8, showing elevated activity in parietal bone compared to frontal segments. This suggests that FGF10 downregulation allows other genes' activities to shape the cranial vault.
title: Joint Multi-Ancestry and Admixed GWAS Reveals the Complex Genetics behind Human Cranial Vault Shape

finding: The study referenced the SNP rs10060073 in the context of analyzing the influences of posture on user interaction within virtual reality environments. It identified a significant original finding associated with this SNP regarding its influence on posture effects during immersive activities. This relates to optimizing user interaction and performance metrics in VR, providing insights valuable for enhancing immersive extended reality applications.
title: VRoot: An XR-Based Application for Manual Root System Architecture Reconstruction

finding: The variant rs33003 in the MSH3 gene was found to be a splitting factor specifically for patients with lower RN (greater than 36.5 but less than or equal to 39.5 units). This was consistent with previous findings regarding its influence on age at onset (AAO).
title: Identification of representative trees in random forests based on a new tree-based distance measure

finding: The variant rs245013 in the MSH3 gene was utilized as a splitting variable for patients with RN greater than 39.5 and less than or equal to 43.5 units. This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic influences on AAO, aligning with prior research.
title: Identification of representative trees in random forests based on a new tree-based distance measure

finding: The SNP rs17070145, related to the KIBRA gene, was found to impact hippocampal function. Specifically, it affected HC-dependent episodic memory, spatial navigation, and learning in older adults (OA), providing a mechanistic understanding of how genetic polymorphisms associated with dopamine receptors could influence spatial cognitive decline with age.
title: L-DOPA enhances hippocampal direction signals in younger and older adults

finding: The SNP rs6883964 was found to disrupt an IRF1 motif within the DLOC24008 locus, which is located near the PTGER4 gene. This disruption was shown to have a high correlation with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) ICE-CREAM scores and was specific to T cells, indicating a significant role in immune cell regulation of PTGER4 expression.
title: A single-cell atlas of transcribed cis-regulatory elements in the human genome

finding: The SNP exhibited a positive 3' aQTL effect size in brain tissue, while showing a median negative effect in other tissues. It was hypothesized that this variant modifies a T/GT/CT-rich motif and alters CstF binding affinity, positively affecting brain-specific RNA binding proteins.
title: Deciphering the Impact of Genetic Variation on Human Polyadenylation

finding: This previously reported SNP reached GWAS-significant evidence for association with cIMT, representing an established genetic factor in cardiovascular risk.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: This SNP was the lead for a woman-only locus associated with cIMT, emphasizing distinct genetic variations between sexes in cardiovascular disease.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: The rs17421627 SNP was identified as a significant variant for MacTel and most accessible in Müller glia and astrocytes. It targeted LINC00461, a long noncoding RNA, and deletion of this locus in retinal organoids significantly downregulated LINC00461, confirming its functional relevance.
title: Single-cell multiome of the human retina and deep learning nominate causal variants in complex eye diseases

finding: The indel <italic>RAD50 K994_E995fs</italic> was classified as a somatic mutation but was reclassified as germline; it was curated as a cancer predisposition mutation on ClinVar.
title: RNAIndel: a machine-learning framework for discovery of somatic coding indels using tumor RNA-Seq data

finding: The SNP rs2736098 in TERT exon 2 was analyzed in the context of TERT expression patterns across nine human cancer cell lines. The analysis confirmed the allelic classifications of monoallelic and biallelic expression (MAE or BAE). All lines confirmed their classification except for the HT-1376 cell line, which appeared to have more biallelic expression than previously reported. The discrepancies in expression levels of active and inactive alleles were also notable in several other lines, underscoring the complexity of TERT expression across the studied cancer lines.
title: Single-cell imaging reveals unexpected heterogeneity of TERT expression across cancer cell lines

finding: The SNP rs78727187 was significantly associated with the phenotype "Comparative height size at age 10" (UK Biobank Field ID: 1697), showing a MAF of 0.6% and a p value of 5.1E-19. This SNP is located in the FBN2 gene.
title: Efficient mixed model approach for large-scale genome-wide association studies of ordinal categorical phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs791357 was identified as a proximal tfQTL for PU.1 and C/EBPβ, significantly associated with decreased neutrophil and monocyte cell counts and linked to expression of the CPEB4 gene, suggesting it may play a role in immune response mediations.
title: Variation in PU.1 binding and chromatin looping at neutrophil enhancers influences autoimmune disease susceptibility

finding: The IFN-γ +874 (rs2435061) TT genotype was identified as a marker for protection against BKV infection, suggesting that specific genetic variants might offer some degree of resilience to BK virus reactivation in immunocompromised patients.
title: The change of lymphocyte subsets and inflammatory cytokine in BK viruria

finding: The SNP rs31517 was associated with ALECT2 amyloidosis, where individuals who were often homozygous for G172 had the variant V40. The study indicated that while this variant was prevalent in these individuals, it could not directly cause the disease and may represent a risk factor instead. The findings suggested that the I-to-V mutation was conservative, not significantly altering the properties of LECT2, and that homozygous individuals might have a higher risk of amyloidosis due to greater concentrations of the amyloid-forming protein.
title: An amyloidosis-associated polymorphism does not alter LECT2 stability in vitro

finding: The rs10065172 variant in the IRGM gene was associated with an increased risk for steatosis in Italian obese children, although it did not impact the progression of liver damage. This finding suggests a potential role of the IRGM gene variant in metabolic disorders.
title: Autoimmunity Risk Gene IRGM is a Master Negative Regulator of Interferon Response by Controlling the Activation of cGAS-STING and RIG-I-MAVS Signaling Pathways

finding: This SNP was associated with RPS23 gene expression during HCort exposure and lay in a YY1 binding motif, indicating a functional variant that influences expression under stress conditions.
title: Common genetic variation impacts stress response in the brain

finding: Not explicitly linked in findings, but placed within a network of SNPs highlighting its potential contributions to disease studies.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: rs1122171 had the strongest association with decayed, missing and filled surfaces (DMFS). The variant was linked to the uncharacterized gene C5orf66 and was observed in significant linkage disequilibrium with other DMFS-associated variants, many overlapping a human craniofacial enhancer. This region demonstrated enhancer activity in developing pharyngeal arches and was implicated in the regulatory interaction with PITX1, a gene connected to tooth and limb development.
title: “Integration of multimodal data in the developing tooth reveals candidate dental disease genes”

finding: At the SLC22A4 locus (rs35260072), associated with itch intensity from mosquito bites, a steady increase in frequency began approximately 9,000 years ago, marking it as a significant target of selection in response to environmental adaptations.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs35395 at the SLC45A2 locus, associated with lighter skin pigmentation, indicated significant selection starting about 13,000 years ago, marking it as a primary target of selection due to varying environmental UV exposure.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs12916 was identified as a strong candidate variant within the 3’ UTR of the gene HMGCR, which is known to be the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis and a target for statins. This SNP showed a high posterior inclusion probability (PIP = 0.99) and was found to be involved in a chromatin loop that interacts with the promoter of HMGCR. Despite being in close proximity to other genes, such as POLK, the data indicated that HMGCR was the causal gene linked to the relevant traits, thus demonstrating the effectiveness of the causal-TWAS method in identifying true genetic signals while minimizing false discoveries.
title: Adjusting for genetic confounders in transcriptome-wide association studies leads to reliable detection of causal genes

finding: The study identified the DAT-K619N variant (rs200712598) in a patient with early-onset parkinsonism and neuropsychiatric disease. This coding variant was present in 22 individuals from exome-sequenced neuropsychiatric patients and was associated with reduced dopamine uptake capacity and increased risk for neuropsychiatric diseases, notably showing a nominally significant association with bipolar disorder in a cohort study (iPSYCH) that analyzed 17,339 samples including 12,327 diagnosed cases.
title: A dominant-negative variant in the dopamine transporter PDZ-binding motif is linked to parkinsonism and neuropsychiatric disease

finding: The SNP rs13153686 was associated with therapeutic responses in glioblastoma treatments, particularly in the context of combining Vascular Normalization and Immune Checkpoint Blockade. The finding highlighted a potential genetic influence on treatment efficacy, making it relevant for personalized therapeutic strategies.
title: Dynamics of repurposing synthetic and natural compounds against WNT/β-Catenin signaling in glioma- An in vivo approach

finding: The SNP rs12658032 was identified as a lead SNP in the MDD GWAS with a p-value of 1.18e-10. It demonstrated consistent associations with multiple psychiatric disorders, including BIP, ADHD, and ASD.
title: Detecting Local Genetic Correlations with Scan Statistics

finding: The SNP rs323509 acted as a lead SNP for BIP with a reported p-value of 8.94e-6. It was part of a locus that showed significant genetic correlation with multiple psychiatric disorders.
title: Detecting Local Genetic Correlations with Scan Statistics

finding: The SNP rs325485 was recognized as a lead SNP for ASD, exhibiting a p-value of 3.25e-7. This finding contributed to the strong genetic correlation observed across the studied psychiatric disorders.
title: Detecting Local Genetic Correlations with Scan Statistics

finding: The UGT3A1 gene variant exhibited a significant association with 5alpha-pregnan-3beta, highlighting its metabolic implications.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The lead variant rs13354746 was associated with the HMGCR gene, an enzyme target for statins, and its risk allele was highly correlated with increased serum TC levels in the Japanese population.
title: Population-specific and transethnic genome-wide analyses reveal distinct and shared genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs112403360, a non-coding intronic variant associated with the ANKH gene, was linked to a predisposition to Alzheimer's disease (AD) based on genome-wide analysis. This study showed that ANKH was upregulated in senescent astrocytes, which are critical in AD development in certain mouse models. Interestingly, the ANKH gene was downregulated in aged mouse brain tissue, particularly in neurons and microglial cells, suggesting that its downregulation may be related to the AD predisposition seen in humans. Cognitively healthy centenarians were found to carry the protective allele of rs112403360, hinting at a potential connection to bone and vascular health, as well as its implications for citrate supply to the brain.
title: Plasma membrane transporter Progressive Ankylosis Protein Homolog (ANKH/Ankh) mediates senescence-derived extracellular citrate and is regulated by DNA damage, inflammation and ageing

finding: The SNP rs6889665 was specifically studied in the context of PRDM9 binding in human spermatogonia. Data from ATAC-Seq showed that the tissue donor was a carrier of the most common European alleles of PRDM9, enabling the direct assessment of its binding at the 13-mer PRDM9 motif. The study noted that this SNP had coverage of 10 reads, all of which were 'T'. This finding underscored the association between this SNP and the potential for meiotic recombination, linking it to increased rates of structural variation and influencing regulatory architecture in neurodevelopment.
title: Mutational bias in spermatogonia impacts the anatomy of regulatory sites in the human genome

finding: The variant rs11745587 in the C5orf56-IRF1-IL5 region showed a nominally significant association with EGPA (P 6.8×10−3), suggesting it is associated with higher eosinophil count and might have subtype specific effects.
title: Genetically distinct clinical subsets, and associations with asthma and eosinophil abundance, within Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

finding: The EGPA susceptibility variant rs1837253 lies upstream of TSLP and is associated with higher TSLP protein secretion and eosinophil counts, with an associated odds ratio of 1.7 for EGPA compared to 1.12-1.27 for asthma.
title: Genetically distinct clinical subsets, and associations with asthma and eosinophil abundance, within Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

finding: The SNP rs1161976348 (5:17276721_G>A) was found in the 3'-UTR of the gene BASP1. The analysis revealed that a higher proportion of cells expressed this SNP at later time-points post anti-cancer treatment, particularly at t96, indicating a temporal expression pattern related to treatment efficacy.
title: Improved SNV discovery in barcode-stratified scRNA-seq alignments

finding: The study found that individuals carrying at least one copy of the T allele at rs5865330 had an increased expression of the Exocyst Complex Component 3 gene (EXOC3), which was associated with a higher risk of asthma. This effect was amplified in youths with high levels of self-disclosure, demonstrating that psychosocial environments significantly modulate the genetic risk for asthma.
title: Psychosocial experiences modulate asthma-associated genes through gene-environment interactions

finding: The rs74656936-GEMIN5 eQTL was established as significant in the CD9hi/C1Rhi fibroblast subtype, but not in other fibroblast or iPSC subtypes. This indicated a subtype-specific regulatory effect of this SNP.
title: Single cell eQTL analysis identifies cell type-specific genetic control of gene expression in fibroblasts and reprogrammed induced pluripotent stem cells

finding: The rs56353548-GEMIN5 eQTL was shown to be significant in the GAPDHhi/SNHG8hi iPSC subtype, while it was not significant in either fibroblast subtype. This finding underscored the cell-type specific nature of eQTL effects.
title: Single cell eQTL analysis identifies cell type-specific genetic control of gene expression in fibroblasts and reprogrammed induced pluripotent stem cells

finding: The rs12055298-GEMIN5 eQTL was significant in the TUBA1Bhi/DCNlo fibroblast type but was not significant in the other subtypes analyzed. This demonstrated that the SNP's impact on gene expression was specific to the fibroblast type.
title: Single cell eQTL analysis identifies cell type-specific genetic control of gene expression in fibroblasts and reprogrammed induced pluripotent stem cells

finding: The rs1866389 SNP, corresponding to the A387P variant of the TSP4 gene, was found to have significant implications in the context of cardiovascular disease. Specifically, lesions in human arteries from individuals carrying the A387P variant displayed higher levels of TSP4, correlating with increased macrophage accumulation. In <italic>ApoE</italic><sup>−/−</sup>/P387-TSP4 knock-in mice, atherosclerotic lesions with the P387 variant accumulated more macrophages and exhibited elevated inflammatory markers compared to lesions bearing the A387 variant. This evidence indicated that the A387P variant was associated with enhanced pro-inflammatory activity and a stronger association with cardiovascular disease.
title: The P387 Thrombospondin-4 Variant Promotes Accumulation of Macrophages in Atherosclerotic Lesions

finding: The rs7731626 SNP demonstrated a colocalized effect with 13 CpGs in the surrounding region of the ANKRD55 and IL6ST genes, with significant correlation in methylation levels observed across these CpGs. This local DNA methylation was inversely correlated with ANKRD55 gene expression, suggesting that the SNP influences MS susceptibility through alterations in methylation.
title: Impact of genetic susceptibility to multiple sclerosis on the T cell epigenome: proximal and distal effects

finding: The SNP rs188222191 reached a P-value of 1.28 × 10^-7, implicating it in the genetic framework associated with cocaine use, particularly near the gene EFNA5, involved in bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.
title: Retrospective Association Analysis of Longitudinal Binary Traits Identifies Important Loci and Pathways in Cocaine Use

finding: SNP rs1014278 showed association with longitudinal cocaine use with a P-value of 1.43 × 10^-7 and was located near the gene EFNA5, emphasizing its potential relevance in addiction and mental health.
title: Retrospective Association Analysis of Longitudinal Binary Traits Identifies Important Loci and Pathways in Cocaine Use

finding: The SNP rs75132056 achieved significance with a P-value of 8.92 × 10^-8, also located close to the gene EFNA5, establishing a link between genetic variants and addiction-related phenotypes.
title: Retrospective Association Analysis of Longitudinal Binary Traits Identifies Important Loci and Pathways in Cocaine Use

finding: The SNP rs4415084 was identified as a breast cancer-associated genetic variant, contributing to differential allele-specific expression (ASE) in breast cancer tumor samples. This SNP was part of a larger study that proposed methods to uncover gene dysregulation due to somatic mutations in noncoding regions of cancer genes. Notably, this finding was underscored by the detection of known allele-specific effects linked to copy number variation and nonsense mediated decay, indicating its potential relevance in cancer-related biological processes.
title: Differential Allele-Specific Expression Uncovers Breast Cancer Genes Dysregulated By Cis Noncoding Mutations

finding: rs11748158 (C/T) was recognized as a regulatory variant located within the 5' UTR region of the IRGM gene, closely linked with rs13361189 (C/T), a GWAS lead variant of Crohn's disease. The variant resulted in decreased binding of KLF17, altering chromatin accessibility and significantly decreasing IRGM expression. Thus, it was linked to the risk of Crohn's disease.
title: Functional variants in hematopoietic transcription factor footprints and their roles in the risk of immune system diseases

finding: This SNP was associated with the SLC45A2 gene, known for its role in light skin pigmentation. Its selection signal indicated a strong evolutionary pressure likely linked to changes in environmental conditions affecting vitamin D synthesis.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: The SNP rs10060207 was linked to hypersialylation in cancer, as discussed by Rodrigues and Macauley (2018). This association provided new insights into the role of glycosylation patterns in influencing inflammation and potential therapeutic strategies for melanoma.
title: Integrated in vivo functional screens and multi-omics analyses identify α-2,3-sialylation as essential for melanoma maintenance

finding: The SNP rs11950562, located at the SLC22A4 gene, had been associated with neuroblastoma susceptibility. It was noted that lower expression levels of SLC22A4 were found in high-risk neuroblastoma (HR) patients compared to non-HR patients (fold change = 0.45, FDR = 2e-44). The study suggested that this interaction between rs11950562 and the expression of SLC22A4 may contribute significantly to the neuroblastoma phenotype.
title: Adopting tipping-point theory to transcriptome profiles unravels disease regulatory trajectory

finding: SNP rs16903930 was positively associated with multiple traits including height, mathematical ability, and education attainment through its location in the intron of the EGFLAM gene. This suggests that this SNP may influence cognitive and physical traits.
title: A novel classification framework for genome-wide association study of whole brain MRI images using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs4242182 was associated with cortical surface area, posterior cortical atrophy, and Alzheimer’s disease, reflecting its role through the MSX2 gene in brain morphology and neurodegenerative conditions.
title: A novel classification framework for genome-wide association study of whole brain MRI images using deep learning

finding: The rs34681760 SNP located in the promoter of TENT4A gene demonstrated a significant association with multiple sclerosis (MS) risk, with a P-value of 2.0 x 10^-11. The association was characterized by a high L2G score correlating with TENT4A mRNA expression levels in monocytes and dendritic cells. Despite this association, no direct experimental evidence was available to elucidate the underlying biological mechanisms.
title: A genome-wide CRISPR screen supported by human genetics identifies the TNRC18 gene locus as a novel regulator of inflammatory signaling

finding: SNP rs73171800 at locus 5q14.3 showed the strongest association with MacTel, correlating with vascular calibre. It was found to have a protective effect against macular thinning, specifically increasing macular thickness, which was previously consistent with findings from other studies.
title: Genetic Disruption of Serine Biosynthesis is a Key Driver of Macular Telangiectasia Type 2 Etiology and Progression

finding: The variant rs7714232 was associated with the expression of MAP3K1, influencing breast cancer outcomes through interactions with an active enhancer and transcription factor GATA3.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The rs16886272 variant similarly regulated MAP3K1 expression in breast cancer by forming contact with a fragment containing a GATA3 binding site, indicating a key role in tumorigenesis.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs27524, located within the gene ERAP1, demonstrated a significant statistical interaction with the SNP rs10484554 located in the HLA-C gene in relation to psoriasis. This interaction resulted in genotypic odds ratios (ORs) exceeding 7.5 when compared to the most protective genotype across the two loci, indicating a strong interaction effect that amplifies the risk associated with each SNP depending on the presence of risk alleles at both loci.
title: GWAIS-Web: A Fast and Secure Web Service for Epistasis Detection in Genome-wide Association Interaction Studies

finding: The SNP rs10040104 was linked to the inflammatory responses involved in the pathogenesis and progression of myeloid malignancies. This association underscored the critical role of inflammation in conditions such as acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), indicating that genetic variations like rs10040104 may influence individual responses to inflammatory conditions in myeloid neoplasms.
title: A MALDI-TOF assay identifies nilotinib as an inhibitor of inflammation in acute myeloid leukaemia

finding: The SNP rs10040118 was associated with the roles of polyploid/multinucleated giant cancer cells in metastasis and disease relapse following anticancer treatment. This finding highlighted the potential impact of genetic variations on cancer cell behaviors, particularly in stress responses such as those leading to senescence.
title: Inhibition of nucleotide synthesis promotes replicative senescence of human mammary epithelial cells

finding: The rs2853669 polymorphism was investigated in the context of glioblastoma prognosis, showing that it interacted with activating tert promoter mutations. The significance of this finding related to patient age at diagnosis, indicating that both the polymorphism and the patient's age may influence the clinical outcomes in glioblastoma cases.
title: Intrinsic-Dimension analysis for guiding dimensionality reduction and data-fusion in multi-omics data processing

finding: The SNP rs6860901 was under strong selection in relation to syndromic myopia genes, indicating that selection favored myopia in this locus among European populations based on its significant association.
title: Detection of adaptation to light environment in myopia-associated loci Diversity of the myopia genetic background

finding: The SNP rs2910164 in miR-146a-3p was associated with increased risk of several cancers, including breast, glioma, and gastric cancer. However, it simultaneously showed protective effects against prostate and gastric cancers. This dual association underscores the complexity of mutations in miRNAs and their influence on disease susceptibility.
title: Changes in miRNA secondary structure can predict mutations associated with cancer and other diseases

finding: Research found a significant association between the ADRB2 rs2053044 polymorphism and blood pressure response to angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors in African American populations, indicating its relevance in hypertension and kidney disease.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers in diabetic kidney disease and its complications: Evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The CREBRF rs373863828 variant was identified to play a protective role against gestational diabetes among Maori and Pacific women with obesity, illustrating its importance in diabetes risk.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers in diabetic kidney disease and its complications: Evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs1697139 SNP was associated with breast cancer risk, where the G/G genotype led to cortisol-dependent repression of MAST4 expression. This repression was reversed after antagonist treatment and linked to increased breast cancer risk, as lower MAST4 expression correlated with reduced relapse-free survival and differences in expression between tumor and normal tissues.
title: Glucocorticoids Unmask Silent Non-Coding Genetic Risk Variants for Common Diseases

finding: The study found that the rs27293 variant of the Lnpep gene was associated with a significantly increased risk of developing juvenile idiopathic arthritis, a condition known to involve TNF-α. Additionally, it was noted that the expression of the minor (risk) allele led to higher IRAP mRNA levels compared to the major (protective) allele, reinforcing the connection between IRAP and TNF-α secretion.
title: Mast cell-mediated inflammation relies on insulin-regulated aminopeptidase controlling cytokine export from the Golgi

finding: Similar to rs16978028, the finding related to rs7705526 indicated that shorter telomere length had a protective causal effect on mLOY, evidenced by significant results when this SNP was excluded during leave-one-out sensitivity analyses. The IVW-RE method also indicated a non-significant trend for this SNP in relation to telomere length and mLOY.
title: Association between mosaic loss of chromosome Y and pulmonary fibrosis susceptibility and severity

finding: The rs373863828 variant (p.Arg457Gln; CREBRF<R457Q</sup> in humans) was strongly associated with increased odds of obesity, with an odds ratio of 1.305 per copy of the risk allele. This variant had a significant effect size on BMI, being the highest known common obesity-risk variant, yet it paradoxically corresponded to a decreased odds of diabetes (odds ratio of 0.586 after controlling for BMI). The variant was especially prevalent in Samoans, with approximately 46% carrying at least one copy.
title: A murine model of the human CREBRFR457Q obesity-risk variant does not influence energy or glucose homeostasis in response to nutritional stress

finding: This SNP was located within LINC01484 with a significant association to AAO (p<0.001). It was noted as a lead independent risk variant correlating with earlier onset.
title: A higher burden of multiple sclerosis genetic risk confers an earlier onset

finding: The SNP rs55715053 was identified as a significant exonic variant associated with thoracic aortic length and was part of gene Fibrillin-2 (FBN2), which has been previously linked to cardiovascular diseases.
title: Thoracic Aortic 3-Dimensional Geometry: Effects of Aging and Genetic Determinants

finding: The SNP rs73348287 was identified as a significant exonic variant associated with thoracic aortic length and was also part of the genetic locus Fibrillin-2 (FBN2). Its association with cardiovascular conditions was noted.
title: Thoracic Aortic 3-Dimensional Geometry: Effects of Aging and Genetic Determinants

finding: The SNP rs13164242 was associated with the transcriptional control by YAP in the context of chromosomal instability (CIN) formation in breast cancer. This finding was established through the identification of the YAP/TEAD complex's role in upregulating the AJUBA signaling pathway, which is linked to aberrant mitosis and tumorigenesis. The study's results indicated that alterations in the YAP pathway could influence CIN, highlighting a potential genetic risk factor within breast cancer pathology.
title: YAP promotes chromosomal instability by transcriptionally activating AJUBA through its super enhancer in breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs4543289 had nominal significance for GxS interactions (p=0.034) in BIP, marking it as a notable positive finding.
title: Sex-Dependent Shared and Non-Shared Genetic Architecture Across Mood and Psychotic Disorders

finding: The eSNP rs1363974 was connected to shared eQTL across various immune cell types and served as a genetic determinant of neutrophil and lymphocyte percentages, underscoring its role in the immune response dynamics.
title: Natural Killer cells demonstrate distinct eQTL and transcriptome-wide disease associations, highlighting their role in autoimmunity

finding: The SNP rs115877304 in NR2F1-AS1 was significantly linked with various functional connectivity traits, contributing to the understanding of network interactions in the brain.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic human brain functional networks

finding: The SNP rs30187, associated with the gene ERAP1, was one of the eQTLs identified in the context of psoriasis. This SNP was also reported as a GWAS hit for psoriasis, establishing a strong link between the genetic variant and the disease.
title: BaseQTL: a Bayesian method to detect eQTLs from RNA-seq data with or without genotypes

finding: The SNP rs56219066 was associated with an increased usage of an intronic PAS in the ELL2 gene. This SNP was also linked to a risk of multiple myeloma, illustrating its potential role in disease susceptibility through mechanisms of alternative polyadenylation.
title: Alternative polyadenylation mediates genetic regulation of gene expression

finding: The rs3822568 SNP in the HOMER1 gene was significantly associated with sleep parameters including sleep latency, sleep efficiency, number of arousals per hour, apnea-hypopnea index (AHI), and theta spectral power in a study involving a Brazilian population. GG carriers exhibited higher sleep latency, reduced sleep efficiency, lower arousals per hour, and lower AHI compared to AA carriers. Notably, despite the associations observed, rs3822568 did not correlate with the presence of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS). Thus, this SNP appeared to influence sleep quality and structure, potentially affecting sleep homeostasis.
title: A single nucleotide polymorphism in the HOMER1 gene is associated with sleep latency and theta power in sleep electroencephalogram

finding: The non-risk allele of rs1501357 in the HCN1 gene was associated with positive selection signals in AFR, with a considerable operational duration estimated at 33,621 years. This allele exhibited a correlation (ρ = 0.68) with the PFS-26 of ST8SIA2, showing lower affinity compared to other SNPs, indicating a unique adaptation related to psychosocial stress in populations.
title: Global adaptive evolution involved in neuroticism and educational behaviors through the spread of anatomically modern humans

finding: This variant was associated with cancer survival and ICB response, identifying it as significant in the prognosis of patients undergoing immunotherapy.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: The rs27765 SNP associated with tumor mutation burden, indicating its relevance in determining somatic changes that may affect immune response.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: The SNP rs10070213 was associated with the regulation of the p53 tumor suppressor pathway in human cancers linked to oncoviruses. This finding highlighted how genetic variations at this locus contribute to the deregulation of critical pathways involved in cancer progression, specifically in the context of oncovirus-induced transformation.
title: Partial EMT and associated changes in cellular plasticity in oncovirus-positive samples

finding: The SNP rs10472291 was identified as having significant clinical associations with diverticular disease, following analyses in the PheWAS context.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome- and Phenome-wide Association Studies of Diverticular Disease in Electronic Health Records with Natural Language Processing enriched phenotype algorithm

finding: The SNP at the SLC22A5 locus (chr5:132389258:T:C) was associated with CSF levels of the metabolite hypaphorine, with a highly significant <italic>P</italic>=1.52e-12.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapping of circulating metabolites in cerebrospinal fluid to uncover biological mechanisms involved in brain-related phenotypes

finding: Similar to rs9939609, possession of the alternate allele for SNP rs2736100 was also linked to shorter telomeres, indicating its relevance in the study of biological aging.
title: Markers, Mechanisms and Metrics of Biological Aging: A Scoping Review

finding: The SNP rs10040126 was associated with drug resistance mechanisms, particularly relating to hypoxia-induced resistance in cancer. Previous findings indicated that the hypoxic conditions in non-small cell lung cancer facilitated cisplatin resistance through pathways involving HIF-1α and mutant p53.
